content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple sections of tissue, appearing to be at least five lymph nodes of varying sizes and shapes. The tissue is stained purple, characteristic of dense lymphoid tissue. They are scattered on the slide, likely representing a lymph node dissection from a colorectal cancer resection. The goal is to screen these nodes for any evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because it is part of the largest and most irregularly shaped lymph node on the slide. The irregular contour raises suspicion for potential tumor infiltration disrupting the normal architecture or extranodal extension. The selected area is specifically at the periphery of the node, which is a critical location to examine for tumor cells in the subcapsular sinus and to assess the integrity of the lymph node capsule. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the largest lymph node on the left side of the image. The specific area of interest is the periphery of the node, where the lymphoid tissue meets the surrounding pericolic fat. This lymph node appears irregular and possibly fragmented. Examining the capsule and the interface with the fat is crucial to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding soft tissue. ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor, so any irregularity at the node's border must be carefully evaluated. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node to check for signs of metastasis. The green box is located on the second lymph node from the top left. This node appears somewhat fragmented and irregular in shape. I am zooming into this specific area to assess the cellular composition and architecture of the lymph node parenchyma, looking for any atypical cells, abnormal glandular structures, or disruption of the normal nodal architecture that would suggest the presence of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node submitted. The green box is focused on one of the smaller lymph nodes in the upper left. I would zoom into this area to assess its architecture and cytology at high magnification. Specifically, I am looking for evidence of metastasis, which often begins in the subcapsular sinus at the periphery of the node. This location is also critical for assessing extranodal extension (tumor spreading into the surrounding fat), which is an important prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my procedure is to examine every lymph node on the slide to determine if cancer has spread. The green box highlights one of the lymph nodes, specifically the one in the upper right quadrant of the image. I am zooming into this area to perform a high-magnification assessment of its architecture and cellular composition. I need to carefully inspect the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma for any atypical cells or glandular structures that would indicate metastasis from the primary colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node present on the slide. The green box is placed on one of the smaller lymph nodes on the right side of the image. I am zooming into this specific lymph node to assess its architecture, including the cortex, paracortex, medulla, and sinuses, to search for any atypical cells or clusters of cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of a lymph node. The majority of the field consists of dense, diffuse sheets of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes, consistent with lymph node parenchyma. This is bordered by a thickened, pink, fibrous capsule. Adjacent to the capsule, at the bottom right, is mature adipose tissue (fat). I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or desmoplastic reaction to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma in this specific field. My impression is that this portion of the lymph node is negative for metastasis; it appears to be a reactive lymph node with a thickened capsule.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see dense lymphoid tissue on the left and bottom, composed of a monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes. On the upper right, there is mature adipose tissue. The interface between the lymphoid tissue and the fat is irregular and appears disrupted. There are small clusters of lymphocytes that seem to be spilling into the adjacent fat. However, I do not see any definite malignant cells, such as atypical glands or large pleomorphic epithelial cells, which would be characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this likely represents an artifactual fragmentation of the lymph node during processing or possibly benign reactive lymphoid spill. A complete examination of the entire node circumference is necessary to definitively rule out metastasis and extranodal extension.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. This is the characteristic appearance of a lymph node parenchyma. There are some small blood vessels present. At the bottom edge, there is perinodal adipose tissue (fat). I do not see any clear evidence of metastatic carcinoma, which would typically present as nests or glands of atypical epithelial cells with large, pleomorphic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. My impression of this specific area is that it is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows the edge of a lymph node adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue (fat cells, the large white circles at the top). The normal lymph node architecture appears to be effaced and replaced by a dense, monotonous sheet of small, dark-staining cells (lymphocytes). A key finding is that these lymphoid cells are infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue, breaking through the lymph node capsule. This feature is known as extranodal extension. In the context of colorectal cancer, the primary goal is to find metastatic adenocarcinoma cells (glandular structures). While I do not see definite malignant glands in this specific field of view, the complete effacement of the node architecture and the presence of extranodal extension are highly suspicious for malignancy. This could represent a lymph node almost entirely replaced by tumor, or potentially a coexisting lymphoma. The pathologist is correctly identifying a critical area of abnormality.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a portion of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The normal lymphoid architecture is partially effaced by an infiltration of atypical cells. These cells are located at the periphery of the node, in the subcapsular sinus, and are also seen breaching the capsule to extend into the surrounding perinodal fat (extranodal extension). The tumor cells are pleomorphic, with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei and are arranged in poorly-formed glands and irregular nests. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma with clear evidence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see the parenchyma of the lymph node, which is composed of dense sheets of small, round lymphocytes. There are open sinusoidal spaces, including a prominent one traversing the center of the field. The cells within the lymphoid tissue and sinuses appear to be benign lymphocytes and histiocytes (sinus histiocytosis). I do not see any definite clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or significant cytologic atypia to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific area is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
